data.title: Can't save files after running Meteor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows10
- extensions: eslint, git history, beautify, powershell

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run meteor in a meteor Project:  myMeteorProject> meteor run
2. try to save file on VS code: 
    2-1. If meteor is finished: It will occur error that the file is protected.
    2-2. If meteor is running: It will crashing. Meteor will crash as well.
3. Choose overwrite
4. On VS code it seems files are saved. But the files are not changed on other editors such as sublime text and atom.

data.title: Test: Terminal runner as default runner
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Complexity: 3
Tests: #27078

- [x] Windows: @Lixire  
- [x] Linux: @bpasero 
- [x] Mac: @aeschli 

One tester could be @Lixire 

### Default detection

- start with a fresh workspace
- install gulp into that workspace
- create a gulpfile that exports some tasks like:
```js
var gulp = require('gulp');

gulp.task('build', function() {
    console.log('Build'); 
});

gulp.task('watch', function() {
    console.log('Watch');
    console.log("src/protocol.ts(413,17): error TS2304: Cannot find name 'TextDocumentClientCapabilities'.");
    console.log("src/protocol.ts(413,17): error TS4033: Property 'textDocument' of exported interface has or is using private name 'TextDocumentClientCapabilities'.");
});
```
- F1 > Run task.

Ensure that the tasks are listed. Selecting a task should execute the task in the terminal.

Additionally try:

- npm: The script tasks should be listed as well as the install and test task.
- TypeScript: create a tsconfig.json and a TS file. F1 > Run Task. Ensure that a `tsc: build tsconfig.json` entry is listed.

### Customize contributed task in tasks.json

- F1 > Run task
- select the customize action (the settings icon to the left of the task name) of the gulp: watch task from above. Ensure that the task is inserted into the tasks.json file and that the editor did open on that file. The inserted task should look like this:
```ts
		{
			"taskName": "gulp: watch",
			"identifier": "gulp.watch"
		}
```
- add a problem matcher to the task by changing the task as follows:
```ts
		{
			"taskName": "gulp: watch",
			"identifier": "gulp.watch"
			"problemMatcher": "$tsc"
		}
```
- ensure that executing the tasks adds two probems to the problem view (the task simply prints two error messages)
- rename the task (change the task name) and ensure that the task is only showing up under `Configured Tasks` (please note that tasks that annotate task coming from an extension can only change top level attributes right now. You can't change for example the terminal reveal or echo behavior)

### Add configured task

- add another task to the tasks.json that is not contributed by an extension. Start with something simple like
```
		{
			"taskName": "dir",
			"command": "dir",
			"type": "shell"
		}
```
- ensure that the task is listed in F1 > Run task and if selected executes in the terminal.

data.title: do not delay variables request when stackframe changes
data.body: currently selecting a stackframe in the CALL STACK view triggers a variable update after a 400ms delay. We should not do this since there is no benefit in delaying the result of a user initiated action.

data.title: Context menu depends on file size
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
I have pretty big webpack bundle.js file (~300K LOC, 20Mb) (unfortunately I can't attach it here because of NDA)
VS Code detected it's JS file and applied JS syntax highlighting (even it took some time).
When I try to find variable definition I right click on it and see very limited context menu: 
- Change All occurences
- Cut
- Copy
- Paste

That's all. 
No any source code navigation related items(i.e. Go to definition, etc.).

Just for test I copied 3K LOC to a new file - everything works fine, I can see complete context menu.
Is there some file size related limitation?

data.title: Ctrl+Backspace not working in search input
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 CU

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any text file and put your cursor after any word in file
2. Open search input with Ctrl+F
3. Write any word in search input and press Ctrl+Backspace

Expected Result: word in search input should be removed.
Actual Result: word in code editor is removed.

2. When the flag is not passed, 'Getting Started' webpage is being opened.

data.title: Unable to download VS Code Linux tarball archive
data.body:
When clicking on the download link for the .tar.gz archive on the https://code.visualstudio.com/ home page, I am redirected to the download page with the URL `https://vscode-update.azurewebsites.net/latest/linux-x64/stable`. Mozilla Firefox issues a certificate error for this page:

> # Secure Connection Failed
>
>An error occurred during a connection to vscode-update.azurewebsites.net. Invalid OCSP signing certificate in OCSP response. Error code: SEC_ERROR_OCSP_INVALID_SIGNING_CERT
>
> * The page you are trying to view cannot be shown because the authenticity of the received data could not be verified.
> * Please contact the website owners to inform them of this problem.

data.title: Paths relative to some parent directory in task with problemMatcher
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
Version 1.12.2
Commit 19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de
Date 2017-05-10T13:16:25.899Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0

- OS Version: Linux 4.4.0-75-generic #96~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Thu Apr 20 11:06:30 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

I'm trying to write tasks for the bazel build system (http://bazel.build). With bazel, it's common to have very large projects, so users often open subdirectories in VSCode, instead of the project root. bazel still prints all messages relative to its workspace root though. For example, given the source tree:

```
my/
  BUILD
  WORKSPACE
  foo.ts
  project/
    BUILD
    bar.ts
    subdir/
      baz.ts
```

Users might open `my/project/` in VSCode (as the workspace location). Now running `bazel build` with a working directory of `my/project`, it'll print errors such as:

```
foo.ts(123): error here
project/subdir/baz.ts(456): another error here
```

Note that paths are relative to the workspace root (`my/` above, the directory containing the WORKSPACE file). `problemMatcher` supports paths relative to the directory opened in VSCode and absolute paths, but AFAICT not paths relative to some parent folder.

I guess this is hard to support in a configuration file format. Maybe it'd be easier if there was an API for an extension to contribute problem matchers (and tasks, for that matter)?

data.title: Extension contributing task
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 
Version 1.12.2
Commit 19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de
Date 2017-05-10T13:16:25.899Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
- OS Version: Linux 4.4.0-75-generic #96~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Thu Apr 20 11:06:30 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

I'm trying to write an extension to support the bazel build system (https://bazel.build/). I want this to be more automated than existing build tasks: users should install the extension, but then the extension should automatically detect the presence of the build system (through `BUILD` files in the source tree), and contribute appropriate actions to the UI ("bazel build" etc).

I can do that, but it seems as if its build tasks would be best represented by a VSCode "task". I could probably implement something with similar functionality by hand, but in particular for long running or continuous builds etc, it'd be nice if I could reuse the existing code. VSCode doesn't seem to expose an appropriate API for that though, unless I'm mistaken?

data.title: Request: Open remote folder via SSH
data.body:
It would be very nice if VS Code could open a remote folder, found via SSH connection. 

Currently I have to use linux Samba share, that is mounted in Windows and it is rather slow - especially for searching and quick opening files. 

It would also resolve problems with versioning, because linux symlinks don't work on Windows (and windows symlinks don't help), changes checking is slow etc.

data.title: Extensions double click: Promise did not implement oncancel
data.body:

1. double click an extension from the extension viewlet
1. check the console:

```
Error: Promise did not implement oncancel
    at Promise_ctor._cancelAction (winjs.base.raw.js:1654)
    at Object.enter (winjs.base.raw.js:805)
    at Promise_ctor._run (winjs.base.raw.js:1068)
    at Promise_ctor.cancel (winjs.base.raw.js:964)
    at Promise_ctor._oncancel (cache.js:21)
    at Promise_ctor._cancelAction (winjs.base.raw.js:1652)
    at Object.enter (winjs.base.raw.js:805)
    at Promise_ctor._run (winjs.base.raw.js:1068)
    at Promise_ctor.cancel (winjs.base.raw.js:964)
    at _Base.Class.derive._creator._cancelAction (winjs.base.raw.js:1311)
```

data.title: activationEvents: ["onContributedCommand"] shorthand for extension's own commands

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I wonder if it would be possible add an alias to all contributed commands so that this part of `package.json`:

```
...
"contributes": {
  "commands": [
    {"command": "extension.firstCommand"},
    {"command": "extension.secondCommand"},
    {"command": "extension.thirdCommand"},
    {"command": "extension.fourthCommand"}
  ]
},
"activationEvents": [
  "onCommand:extension.firstCommand",
  "onCommand:extension.secondCommand",
  "onCommand:extension.thirdCommand",
  "onCommand:extension.fourthCommand",
  "workspaceContains:.extensionSpecificFile"
],
...
```

could instead be written as follows:

```
...
"contributes": {
  "commands": [
    {"command": "extension.firstCommand"},
    {"command": "extension.secondCommand"},
    {"command": "extension.thirdCommand"},
    {"command": "extension.fourthCommand"}
  ]
},
"activationEvents": [
  "onContributedCommand",
  "workspaceContains:.extensionSpecificFile"
],
...
```

This may help catching bugs when a new command is added to an extension but a developer forgot to add it to the `activationEvents` list.

Thank you.

data.title: Disable typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled and javascript.referencesCodeLens.enabled
data.body: I think we settled that we do not want to enable code lense by default.

data.title: Wrongly guess encoding as Windows 1252 or ISO-8859-2

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.12.2 (1.12.2) 
  `19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de`
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5 (16F73)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Creates a YAML file, with some french text, make sure it is saved it as utf8

    ```yaml
    property:
      summary: "Spécifications Swagger"
   ```

2. Make sure the default encoding is utf8 in the `settings.json`

    ```
        "files.autoGuessEncoding": true,
        "files.encoding": "utf8",
    ```

3. Reopen the file, guessed encoding is Windows 1252. Another side effect is that the line with accents is marked as modified as soon as the file is opened

    ```yaml
    prop:
      summary: "SpÃ©cifications Swagger"
    ```

The only workaround is to reopen the file with a different encoding, which is cumbersome when you work with a load of files.

If the same text, encoded as `UTF-8`, is saved in other file extensions, reopening this file show guesses with different encodings, like ISO-8859-2.

I have files with different encoding, so I'd like _vscode_ to guess from content, but here _vscode_ zealously try other encodings while UTF-8 works and is the default encoding. Did I miss something, or is something misconfigured ?

data.title: Autocomplete from all files in project.
data.body:
I have the following scenario in javascript (nodejs).

Function `a` exports an object which consists of other functions. The output of function `a` is passed as parameter to function `b`. As I use the parameter `a` in function `b` there is no intellisense whatsoever. 
What I am asking is how to enable intellisense from all files in the project if even possible. There is such thing by default in WebStorm and Atom and it's really helpful. 
Otherwise, intellisense when modules are directly required is flawless.

data.title: Travis build cannot test extension (missing lib of node-native-keymap)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Travis CI Build System

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write an extension
2. Try to run tests automated (like described on code. https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/testing-extensions#_running-tests-automatically-on-travis-ci-build-machines)

The problem is, that some native packages are used and those tend to break the build:
https://travis-ci.org/buehler/typescript-hero/builds/237070478#L608

I searched a while now, but I don't find a solution to the problem.

Cheers
Chris
